Chapter 5: Documents

Introduction

The chapter focuses on the documentation required in insurance, particularly for fire and special perils policies. It covers proposal forms, risk inspection reports, cover notes, policy drafting, endorsements, and related processes.

A. Proposal Form

The proposal form is the foundational document for obtaining insurance. It typically follows a standard format as per tariff regulations.

1. Contents of the Proposal Form

Details about the Proposer

  • Name, address, contact details
  • Business type and paid-up capital
  • Parties with an insurable interest, including financial institutions
  • Risk location and insurance period
  • History of insurance acceptance or rejection
  • Premium and claims data for the last three policy periods

Coverage Details

  • Options to exclude risks like floods, riots, terrorism, etc.
  • Coverage for plinth and foundation, if required
  • Add-on cover requirements

Details of Property

  • Type of property (e.g., residence, office, warehouse)
  • Hazardous goods storage information
  • Building specifics like age, height, construction material, and fire protection devices

Sum Insured Details

  • Basis of insurance: market or reinstatement value
  • Block-wise values for buildings, machinery, furniture, and stocks
  • Add-on cover values (e.g., architect fees, debris removal)

Declaration Clause

Proposer’s statements form the basis of the contract. Misrepresentation allows insurers to void the contract.

B. Risk Inspection Report

For complex risks like large factories or industrial complexes, an inspection report is submitted by insurers' engineers.

1. Objectives

  • Assist underwriters in determining premium rates and terms
  • Recommend risk improvement measures
  • Gather historical insurance and claims data
  • Estimate probable maximum loss and set retention levels

2. Scope

General Information

  • Proposer’s details, history, and factory description

Lighting, Heating, and Power

  • Compliance with government regulations for electrical installations and power sources

Process of Manufacture

  • Hazards arising from manufacturing processes
  • Storage of raw materials and waste disposal
  • Machinery details and lubrication practices

Exposure

  • Construction and occupancy of neighboring buildings
  • Fire hazards and separation measures

Fire Protection

  • Portable extinguishers, hydrants, sprinkler systems
  • Fire brigade proximity and water supply sources

Management and Supervision

  • Housekeeping practices, waste disposal, machinery maintenance, and employee relations

Moral Hazard

Assessment of proposer’s efficiency, respectability, and past failures.

C. Cover Note

Temporary evidence of insurance issued before the final policy.

Contents

  • Policy number, period, property covered, perils, and sum insured
  • Premium, service tax, and payment details

D. Policy Drafting

Policies are drafted based on information from the proposal form and cover note.

1. Policy Schedule

  • Contains details of the insurance contract, including block-wise amounts for buildings, machinery, stocks, and furniture

2. Warranties and Clauses

  • General and specific warranties related to non-hazardous goods and fire safety
  • Special clauses like Earthquake Extension Clause

E. Endorsements

Amendments to the policy issued for changes during the policy period.

Common Types

  • Name or address changes
  • Adjustments in the sum insured or insurance period
  • Alterations in insured property or coverage

F. Renewal Notices

Issued as a courtesy before policy expiry. Includes revised terms based on changes during the policy period.
